body: Great, I'll merge it in. Thanks to both of you for fixing and testing :-)
LGTM, although I don't think the added test in `QueryParserTest` is related at all? It's fine and unharmful though, so I will agree to merging that in.
This PR has not been updated for a while and I feel like the approach I took is not the right one so I'm going to close it for now.

Hmm seems something is odd with the github mirror ... The commit has been made on our primary git repo, but not synced to master on github. See for yourself: https://git-wip-us.apache.org/repos/asf?p=metamodel.git
Now it should be updated, thanks to INFRA. Can you give it an updated look @albertostratio ?
LGTM @kaspersorensen
LGTM
LGTM
Also LGTM. Not tested at all, though (by me, I mean :)).
But there are a few new unittests, did you notice those? (can be hard because the diff is towards master).
Nono, I just meant _I_ didn't test it :-)
Also implemented this for CSV module now. And added a 'session' abstraction to encapsulate the state that is needed while applying column names for a table.
Let's wait with reviewing this until #96 has been merged and master merged here.
Code mostly looks good. But it is quite a bit more complicated than I expected.

Correction:

It's actually also a third thing that is added, namely stripping of illegal field name characters, see METAMODEL-246
Changed as per review remarks. What do you think now?

Looks good! Maybe I'd let the current `DefaultColumnNamingStrategyTest` be `DelegatingIntrinsicSwitchColumnNamingStrategyTest`. That it is the default is maybe less relevant for the test than what it really is testing. But that's up to you, not a deal breaker for me.
Renamed it. Will merge it now then.
Yep. A bit "dangerous" to still get it with `ColumnNamingStrategies.defaultStrategy()`, but nevermind.  :)
Should be ready for re-review now :)
Single very, very minor thing. Merge if you don't care :)
Code looks good to me, though there was a few surprises.
Created METAMODEL-247 to represent this fix.
+1 from me.
LGTM!
I've updated this PR. Maybe you can check it again @LosD ?
LGTM! :)

Oh wow that is nasty. But if that's what it takes, that's what it takes. 

LGTM!

@kaspersorensen just wondering we want to remove the deprecated methods in 5.x branch?
Shouldn't we just do it in master?
We could do it in master, but I guess it seems nicer to only do that sort of thing when it aligns on a bigger release.
Are all the deprecations old-ish? It might be a major release, but if we can avoid throwing out stuff that has been deprecated only a few months ago, it would be best.

The most recent deprecations where introduced in MM 4.4 AFAIK. Those where related to the split of FunctionType into AggregateFunction and ScalarFunction interfaces. So the deprecations have been there since the release date of 4.4.0: 2015-10-12.
Half a year is probably reasonable when we don't have an official policy about keeping depreciations for a certain amount of time.
The only worry I have is that this change introduce API changes that could break compilation for minor release
I agree Henry, that's why I wanted to put it on the 5.0 branch so that the expectation is also managed a bit :-)
Maybe we should do shout out to dev@ list to check if anyone still in 5.0 and ok to add this breaking API changes?
I'm not sure I understand what you mean Henry? 5.0 isn't out yet so I guess no one will be depending on it yet?

Ah I am so sorry, I need more dose on caffeine =(
I apologize for the confusion.

What I meant was, would anyone in 4.0 still need it to be around for 5.0.
Aha yes... Let's ask that.
Travis failure seems unrelated (a failed Cassandra startup)
Travis error seems unrelated.

I feel a bit like I am missing a unit test for this kind of usage.
An I wonder if that will reveal a slight abstraction issue... The reader today takes a Resource as a constructor argument. Would you have any resource to provide it with when you are yourself providing the lines of data?
I am providing the lines of data. I need to be able to use this class without the BufferReader. I will add a unit test.
I need to wait for this PR: https://github.com/apache/metamodel/pull/103 if I am to avoid conflicts.

I know nothing about Mongodb, but code looks good :)

It does uncover one (unrelated) thing, though: It seems Mongo2 & 3 modules are _very_ similar (a quick glance shows no difference in your changes for 2 & 3), which makes me think more more stuff might belong in common?

Completely agree @LosD. When applying the changes I thought the same. I was about to start refactoring the code but I thought that I shouldn't do this within this PR.

I'd open a new jira to sort this out, what do you think?
Yeah, that makes sense.

Jira created: [METAMODEL-1089](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/METAMODEL-1089)

Thank you @LosD

+0

Code is acceptable from me, but I think it would be better to separate "parser" from "reader" here. A reader is a stateful thing IMO - it has a pointer/cursor to some data that it is reading through and it is also closeable. The parsing part however can have a different scope or maybe even be completely stateless. So I would prefer if we make two different classes for it (the reader will probably use the parser, but not the other way around).
OK to merge? Anyone?
+1 from me, but again my MongoDB knowledge is pretty limited. :)
Thank you! I'll wait another day for anyone who like to comment on this and then will merge it

+1 from me too.

A side-note: Have anyone checked if the same fix can be applied to e.g. CouchDB or other data context implementations? I think a similar approach of using that `allSelectItemsAreColumns` flag is used in other places.

Wait what ... Hmm I see that this is actually a fix that works functionally, but will mean that if you use an alias then the query will not be optimized at all. Is that what we want? I can live with it, since functionality is more important than non-functionals. But some people could take a big performance hit over this if they use an alias. Would be better to fix that too.
I agree @kaspersorensen. I've just pushed some changes to optimize the query even though it contains aliases.
Great, +1 from me!
Cool! Thank you @kaspersorensen and @LosD. I'll merge this.
Travis error seems unrelated (CouchDB timeout)
I read your JIRA issue description, and if you want to reproduce in a unittest, you _could_ do that in the MySQL integration test maybe?

I would love to, but I'm almost sure it won't trigger the error. I tried making a test that almost copied exactly what the DataCleaner table lookup analyzer does, but still didn't seem to trigger the issue. Didn't do it inside the integration setup though, I'll see if that makes a difference.

I added a test (and did some general fixing up... The test assumed that non-system tables besides Sakila existed, and updated the MySQL driver, since the old one had problems with milli/microsecond precision).

Unfortunately, my test does _not_ break on MySQL without my fix, I simply can't get it to fail. Still have no idea why it breaks in some situations and not others. I was hoping that you might have some idea or insight.

But travis seems to fail somehow now?

```
Tests in error: 
  MysqlTest.testCompiledQueries:417->AbstractJdbIntegrationTest.getConnection:104 Â» IllegalState
```
-1, I don't think these changes are viable. Please see review remark.

Sorry for the long wait - I didn't realize that you had changed the branch since my remark.

+1 and let's merge! :)
+1, let's merge
My bad, forget the silly integration test pattern we use :)
(By the way could it be possible to get Travis to use some of these databases? Every time I use one of the integration tests, it seems to have bitrottet quite a bit because no one ever runs them)

It would be nice yes. I know travis has support for various DBs like CouchDB and so on (which we use). Maybe take a look if MySQL is also there. If it is, let's make a story about implementing automatic tests of it.

Just checked. It (and Postgres) is there. 

A danger may be memory use.
I doubt that will be too bad. But anyways, will you create the issue, then you have my LGTM on this PR :)
Here you go: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/METAMODEL-1096 :)
LGTM! :)

Seems it has kept your (somewhat old) remarks from the early commits @LosD. Maybe you can do me a favor and delete them so we can have a fresh view on the PR? The EOLs where fixed and you're more than welcome to post other remarks too :)
I've seen this before for EOLs. I guess it's because it confiders it another line
By the way, API Blueprint seems to be a good alternative to Swagger. Then apiary.io can be used as a mock server.
I'd maybe use POST for the SQL-like query, so UPDATE and INSERT can be performed safely.
We do not allow UPDATE or INSERT in the query interface. It's literally just a facade for `DataContext.executeQuery(String)` (which is just for SELECT queries).
That settles that, then ☺
Aw man. Same branch.
No but it has the other branch as it's parent
But commit 0a82d13b19ea0f8aa3aabcd140caaf3274a8e5b4 is the only substantial piece so far.
OK let's merge this and maybe some day improve it as per my remarks.
Looks solid.
Ok I'm gonna continue down this path then ...

Added a JDBC factory too and fixed a bunch of the TODOs in the code. I suggest taking the PR as a candidate for merging now as it is quite a lot of work to make all the factories in one PR and I'd love to offer those as independent starter issues for people new to MetaModel.

`throws UnsupportedResourcePropertiesException` or not `throws UnsupportedResourcePropertiesException` seems more than a little bit chaotic. In some cases there are methods that calls a method which has `throws UnsupportedResourcePropertiesException` directly, without adding that to its own signature.

That is pretty confusing... In my mind, either `UnsupportedResourcePropertiesException` should be a checked exception (I know, I know... Will never happen), or not declared. This is just chaos.

Overall idea is brilliant (of course I instantly think "Hey, OSGi ServiceFactory!", but this is close enough :smile:).

I'm _very_ happy nothing ended up in MetaModel-full as initially suggested in METAMODEL-1099, as that is something I think we should deprecate because of all the dependency issues it instantly brings to anyone using it. This might even make MM-full less interesting.
Updated the ResourceUtils according to review feedback/discussion - added javadocs to explain why/when the exception can be expected.
OK I will merge it in as per lazy consensus in terms of actual votes cast, and positive feedback remarks.
This branch has now been updated with the new SPI provided in METAMODEL-1099. Shall we merge this (into 5.x)? Please vote :)
Fixed unittest, please review.
Travis is failing because you forgot the license header for the new class/file.

I guess this makes no functional difference to anyone using the the old reader, it just opens up the parser for usage from outside the reader?

My only (minor) objection is that unit testing the parser should probably not be part of the test of old reader, but a separate test for the new parser class, and the old unbuffered test should still be in place to make sure that use hasn't been broken.
LGTM
LGTM!
I have created the issue https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/METAMODEL-1102 and added the improvements suggested by Kasper.
I agree that this needs to be fixed and it seems like a good fix. Just a remark that we should also support empty string operands. Probably worth a unittest too :)
Whoopsie, yes

Empty strings now supported.

We're still pretty far from full LIKE support as we're missing single character (_), character lists ([abc] much like regex), negation ([!abc]) and ESCAPE. However those are simply missing features and not a  bug like this. I'll create a lower-priority issue with that.
